sn15.8:4.1: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove.
sn15.8:4.2: Then a certain brahmin went up to the Buddha,
sn15.8:4.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn15.8:4.9: how many eons have passed, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of eons.”
sn15.8:5.1: “But sir, can you give a simile?”
sn15.8:5.3: “Consider the Ganges river from where it originates to where it enters the ocean. Between these places it’s not easy to calculate
sn15.8:5.4: how many grains of sand there are, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of grains of sand.
sn15.8:5.5: The eons that have passed are more than this.
sn15.8:5.7: how many eons have passed, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of eons.
sn15.8:5.10: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.
sn15.8:5.11: For such a long time you have undergone suffering, agony, and disaster, swelling the cemeteries.
sn15.8:5.12: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed from all conditions.”
sn15.8:6.1: When he said this, the brahmin said to the Buddha:
sn15.8:6.3: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
